repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Before, only the last capture's range would be counted for injection. Now all captured ranges will be counted in the ranges array. This is more intuitive, and also provides a nice solution/alternative to the "scoped injections" issue.

---

### Before

For e.g. rust docstring injections, we would have to do the following:

```scm
(line_comment
  (doc_comment) @injection.content
  (#set! injection.language "markdown")
  (#set! injection.combined))
```

which would infect our query file with some yucky combined injections, and blend together different docstring sections where it would be undesirable.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e9e52571-4efb-49fb-bc0c-62d828316e42)

(note the incorrect highlighting of the second `Hello` header)

### After

Using the following query:

```scm
((line_comment
  (doc_comment) @injection.content)+
  (#set! injection.language "markdown"))
```

we get this result:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/435ac192-29b6-49b7-acfb-349abab21b0f)

which is more correct and avoids the use of combined injections

comment_data.body: If it's a `fix`, I don't think a news entry is needed (and it would make backporting harder).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -214,7 +214,8 @@ TERMINAL
 
 TREESITTER
 
-• todo
+• |treesitter-language-injections| now support multiple `@injection.content`
+  captures per pattern, which will still all be parsed as one tree.

comment_regular_data.body: What would be the consequences for queries (e.g., in nvim-treesitteer)?

I only found one language with quantified injection content captures (`yuck`) but both patterns set `(#set! injection.combined)` anyway, so there is no effect. I think the benefit is we can even remove `(#set! injection.combined)` for them, but not necessary
Well, I'm asking more about the other way around: `injection.combined` we'd want to remove/replace with that.

Ah- I think many instances of `injection.combined` can be replaced with this (I even see a comment for it in the `liquid` injections), but some cases will be blocked by https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/27504

I think in general anything not blocked by the above (that is not a template-style language combined injection) can be replaced with this style of injection

But that replacement would be a regression, right? So the actual change would be blocked until the minimum Nvim version is 0.12?

(Unless we can backport this?)
Yeah it would be. I don't mind backporting and changing this to a `fix`, it seems like the previous behavior can't have been the intended behavior
Agreed, sounds like a plan! (Then you can update the queries here as well -- the HTML injections for Markdown should profit ;))

Darn, it actually looks like the html injections should stay combined. Doesn't really benefit from the quantified injection style (e.g. in `bold`, the inner part is still not bold. I think that refers to a different issue...). Plus something like `*italic here*` would not get properly combined with a quantified pattern, because the italic node interrupts the two tag nodes.
I think the lint failure is a flake
Yes, that keeps popping up. I can't wait to replace luals.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: fix(treesitter): support multiple `@injection.content` captures
